loans.name: Mariafe

texts.en:
Mariafe P. is from the village of Dapacan in Alto Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Mariafe is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Mariafe owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily-use products such as canned goods, noodles, sugar, coffee, milk, shampoo, soap & toothpaste, in the local community. Mariafe has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Mariafe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mariafe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Mariafe is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mariafe from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Calachuchi Group

texts.en:
Jelyn B. is from the village of Sapang Ama in Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old. Jelyn is the leader of a 2-member loan group sponsored by GDMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Calachuchi.

Jelyn is married and has one young child. To make a living, Jelyn makes and sells longaniza sausage to the local community. Jelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Jelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jelyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be Jelyn's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Gulayim

texts.en:
Gulayim E. is 39 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. She has been selling bread for the past 15 years and has become known as a reliable supplier of high quality goods. Her husband is a driver who helps Gulayim transport her products to the local markets. She started her bsuness in 1995 with the initial sum of 20,000 KGS and managed to develop her business and buy a truck for transportation.
 
To expand her business, Gulayim borrowed two loans from Bai-Tushum and Partners, which were used as intended and repaid without any delays. Now Gulayim plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to open a new store and increase her floating capital.

About Bai-Tushum: 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To open a new bread store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more wood and tools

loans.name: Mira's Group

texts.en:
Mira B. K. is the treasurer of this group.  She is 37 and married. Mira is a resident of Kochkor, a small town in the Isykul region. Mira works as an inspector for the Regional Electro Station and her husband is an excavator driver.  They have three children. Two of her sons are students and live with their parents.  In order to earn additional money to cover family expenses, the family started to breed livestock animals. They started two years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms. And now reselling some animals after fattening, they make 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase livestock animals for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul D. is the leader of this group. She is 54 and married. Baktygul is a resident of Kochkor, a small town in the Isykul region. She has a daughter and two sons.  All her children are married and live with their families.  Baktygul herself works as a social worker. She and her husband also breed livestock animals to make additional money.  By reselling some animals after fattening, they make 3,000 soms per month. Baktygul hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase one farm animal in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future, she wants to improve their living conditions.

loans.name: Benson Ngigi

texts.en:
Benson Ngigi is 57 years old and married to Elizabeth who contributes to the family income. Benson is a farmer and keeps both pigs and dairy cows. He has been in the industry for three years with an income of Kshs. 14,000 per month.

This is his third loan from KADET LTD, after successfully servicing the previous loan well and on time. He wants to use the loan to buy more pigs to raise and sell later. He hopes to expand his farming activity and be able to supply his customers with enough dairy products and pork.

loans.use: To buy more pigs.

Alejandra has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alejandra joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alejandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used for additional capital for her business. Alejandra is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Alejandra from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Seydilda

texts.en:
Seydilda D. is a 54-year-old farmer and has three children. He graduated from agricultural college and worked as a tractor-driver in his local area. In order to support his family and find a means of subsistence, he decided to engage in cattle breeding and land cultivating with perennial herbs, which serve as a concentrate of forage for his cattle. His wife helps him develop their family business and sells their milk yield to the local diary factory.  

Seydilda wants to take a loan of 70,000 KGS to buy milk cows, which will allow him to increase the milk yield. With the revenues, he plans to buy his own tractor in order to provide services in harvest gathering to farmers.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.name: Heide

texts.en:
Heide A. is 45 years old, married and supports her family by operating one business venture: a spice and vegetable selling business. She lives in 4th Street, Brgy. Progreso, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her spice and vegetable selling business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,500. 

Heide is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can continue to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom.  Heide aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital to buy vegetables and spices to sell

loans.name: Judith Auma

texts.en:
Judith O. is 32 years old; married to Julius and they have six children aged between two and twelve years old. Her husband has a cyber cafe that he runs and this adds to the family's income.

Judith has a cereals business that she operates at Sanjwero market in Homabay. She has been in this business for the past three years. Judith is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her buy more maize to add to her stock. The profits made from this business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

Her desire is to expand her business and make enough profits that will enable her to meet the needs of her family and even improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy more maize to add to her stock.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen J. is 40 years old and is married to George.  They come from Katito and have four children between the ages of 20 years and 14 years old. 

Hellen has a food Kiosk that she has been running for the past four years. She is applying for her second loan from Kadet Ltd to enable her to buy food ingredients like flour, cooking fat, sugar, salt etc.  She is also in dire need of plates and cups to add to her stock. Hellen earns a montlhy income of Kshs 5,000. The profits made from this business will be used to pay school fees for her children. 

Her desire is to be able to open up a big hotel one day in the future

loans.use: Buy food ingredients, plates and cups to add to her stock.

loans.name: Esther Mwikali

texts.en:
Esther Mwikali is a 26-year-old single lady. She runs a retail shop at Mlolongo that is a transit area and very busy. Her customers are both residents of Mlolongo and people in transit. She was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Kitengela office.

Esther has been running this business for a period of two years and her monthly profit is 9,000 KES. This loan of 20,000 KES is her second loan from KADET. The first loan of 10,000 KES was paid well and on time. She plans to use 10,000 KES to increase stock of sugar, 5,000 KES for rice, and 5,000 KES to increase stock of flour and snacks for sale. If this loan boosts the business, Esther plans to expand it to wholesale.

Esther describes herself as hardworking and ambitious, and she dreams of becoming a big wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To increase stock of sugar, rice, flour and snacks

loans.name: Po's Group

texts.en:
This group loan, which consists of four members, is located in Anlong Ta Sek Leu village in Kandal province. The members plan to use the loans they obtain for different purposes.

Mr. Po D. is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. He and his wife, Mrs. Savey Choem, are farmers who own a five-hectare plot of land where they grow rice and taro to sell to support their family living. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to grow taro in the field. So, to improve production, Mr. Po D. is asking for a loan to buy taro root for this purpose. 

He is 51 years old and he is a father of five children, three of whom are farmers while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy taro root.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha N. lives in the Masanafu Lugala neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school the other one is two months old. She also takes care of additional family members (her parents).

Aisha has a business of selling second hand clothes (jeans). She has been in this business for 3 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Aisha sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Aisha has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand clothes jeans.

The main business challenge(s) for Aisha include seasonality and ever increasing prices for second hand clothes. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing clothes herself. Aisha lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes (jeans).

loans.name: Samuel Ndirangu

texts.en:
Samuel Ndirangu M., aged 30 years, operates a retail shop at the Bissil Market, which is a very busy market. He sells his goods to Bissil residents and livestock traders who come to Bissil every day to sell their livestock. He is married to Wairimu, a farmer, and together they have a son and a daughter in nursery school and baby class respectively. He was introduced to KADET by the credit officer.

Samuel has been running his retail shop for a period of two years and he makes a monthly profit of 14,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs). With his first loan with KADET LTD, Samuel plans to use the whole Kshs 10,000 to increase his stock of rice, sugar and flour for sale. If the loan boosts the business, he will expand his business to a wholesale one.

Samuel, who describes himself as hardworking and ambitious, dreams of becoming a wholesaler and opening other branches. He also hopes to buy a lorry (truck) for transporting his goods.

loans.use: To increase his stock of rice, sugar and bundles of flour for sale

loans.name: Sabira's Group

texts.en:
Sabira K. is the leader of this group.  She is 68 and married. Her husband is retired so he has free time, which he spends breeding cattle. Sabira has five daughters and three sons. All the children are married and live separately with their families, except the youngest son. In order to make money, the family breeds cattle and earns 5,000 KGS monthly reselling them after they are fattened. With money received from this loan, Sabira wants to purchase more cattle to resell.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

In 2009, Ronald joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronald has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ronald is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Ronald from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Khcyorng's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Khcyorng S. H., 47 years old, is the group leader selected by the four members of a group loan in Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. 

He is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows sapota (a fruit) to sell to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Tang H. Tey, is a rice seller who is able to earn some profit to support her family. Although they work hard, they earn a small income. To improve his family's standard of living, Mr. Khcyorng S. H. is applying for a loan to start a new business by buying beef to sell. He is the father of four children, one of whom is an air-conditioner repairer while the others are students.

loans.use: to buy beef

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita H. is from the city of Mantic Tangub. She is 45 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. Teresita owns and operates a pedicab transport business. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a vehicle

loans.name: James Mwangi

texts.en:
James has practiced farming in Naivasha since 2006. He is 56 years old and takes care of his two children all by himself since his wife passed on.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He repaid his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to plant potatoes and pay his casual workers with the loan amount. 

In the future, James hopes to buy a posho mill which will supplement his farming income.

loans.use: to buy potatoes to plant and to pay his casual workers

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine A. is from the village of Bunawan in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Josephine is the leader of a 3-member loan group sponsored by GDMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Blueberry.

Josephine is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily-use products, such as sugar, canned goods, milk, coffee, pancit, shampoo, soap & toothpaste, in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Josephine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Josephine's first loan taken from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: You's Group

texts.en:
This loan group has four members. They have selected Mrs.You K. to be the group leader. They will use their portions of the group loan in different ways to support their families. The members live in Anlong Ta Sek Leu Village in Kandal Province. 

Mrs. You K. and her husband, Mr. Khut Sieng, are farmers who own a two-hectare (~ 5-acre) plot of land. They grow rice and sugar cane which they sell to support their family. Mrs. K. has a problem, because is time to grow rice in her field, but she does not have enough rice seed to grow. So, to improve production, Mrs. You K. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed.

She is 47 years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children are employed in a  garment factory and the other is an iron welder.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora A. is from the village of Olango. She is 53 years old. Aurora is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Aurora plants, harvests, and sells rice. Aurora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Aurora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Aurora is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Aurora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, such as manure

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily A. is from the village of Deboloc in Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Emily is widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily-use products, such as dried fish, bagoong (fish paste), canned goods, sardines, pancit (noodles), shampoo, soap, & toothpaste in the local community. Emily has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Emily joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emily from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Frisca's Group

texts.en:
Frisca E. is from the village of Macabibo in Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old. Frisca is the leader of a 2-member loan group sponsored by GDMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Magnolia.

Frisca is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Frisca grows and sells fruits and vegetables. Frisca has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 800 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Frisca joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Frisca is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Frisca from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, such as manure

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
N. Farida lives in the Makerere Kikoni neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Farida sells charcoal.  She has been in this business for 4 years and she works 7 days a week. Farida sells her products retail at the market.    

Farida has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. Farida's main business challenge is transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to buy a plot of land.   

Farida lives in a home that she rents with electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expense is rent.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Yab's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Yab P. is a loan group leader. He has been selected by the other four members of the loan group. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, but all hope that it will improve their family's standard of living. The members live in Lekh Bei Village in Kandal Province. 

He is a taxi driver who uses a trailer for taxi transportation. His taxi business supports his family. His wife, Mrs. Chreb Vet, does housework and cooks delicious food for her family. Mr. Yab P.'s trailer is too old to use, so he is applying for a loan to buy another trailer. 

He is 29-year-old and he has four children, two of whom are students. The others are too young to work or study. On the day that the loan was disbursed, Mr. Yab P. was busy working. Instead, his wife, Mrs. Chreb Vet, received the loan for him. The photo above is of Mr. Yab P.'s wife.

loans.use: To buy another trailer

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Saing H. is a forty-three-year-old cloth vendor who lives in Kompong Chhnang Province. Her husband assists her in her business. She sells clothes for both men and women from her store in the local market. This family can earn an income of approximately $6 per day. She is married with five children, all of whom are single and studying in school. Bet is an energetic woman who never wastes time. She works to earn the money and inspire her children. 

Saing H. needs to pay the school fee for her two children, but her personal account does not have enough funds. To solve this problem, Saing H. would like to request a loan to pay her children's school fee.

loans.use: To pay school fees

loans.name: Oeurn's Group

texts.en:
This loan group consists of four members who live in Stueng Chrov Village in Kandal Province. They have selected Mrs. Oeurn C. to be the group leader. The members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes, all of which will improve their families' living standards.  

Mrs. Oeurn C. is a housewife who cooks food for her family and looks after her children. Her husband, Mr. Mech Srey, is a traditional Khmer healer who earns some money to support his family. Mrs. Oeurn C. has a problem because her husband is ill, so Mrs. Oeurn C. is requesting a loan to insure her husband’s health. 

She is 50 years old and the mother of four children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory, one is a beautician, and the others attend the public school.

loans.use: To insure her husband’s health

loans.name: Jospine Minayo

texts.en:
Jospine Minayo L. is 37 years old. She is married to Johana Mugavale who is employed and provides additional income for the family. They have five school-going children. The family lives in Eldoret, Kenya. Jospine sells charcoal and has a charcoal store. She has been in this business for eight years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs.5,000.

Jospine learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area. She is applying for her first loan of Kshs. 20,000 from KADET LTD, She intends to buy more bags of charcoal to sell to her customers during this festive season when the demand is very high. She plans to use the anticipated profits to expand her  business.

In the future, she wishes to start poultry farming since both businesses have proven to be very profitable in the area. Her deeper desire is to see her children realize their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. lives in the Busega neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is divorced and has 6 children, four of whom are now in school. Annet has a bar. She has been in this business for two months and she works 7 days a week. Annet sells her products in a retail shop.    

Annet has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more soda and beer.     

Annet's main business challenge is transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked bar. Annet lives in a home that she owns with electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soda

loans.name: Puth

texts.en:
Puth S., age 38, is a married man who lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. He is the father of four school-aged children, one of whom is married. To earn a living, Puth S. is employed as building worker. He always spends at least eight hours per day in the construction field. His wife sells vegetables and is also a homemaker who cooks delicious meals for the family. 

Puth S. faces difficulties with his traveling needs because he always pays a lot of money to a taxi driver when he and his family wants to get to work or to go anywhere. Therefore, Puth S. hopes to reduce the amount he spends on transportation by using his loan to purchase a used motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike.

loans.name: Ou's Group

texts.en:
This loan group consists of five people who live in Kaev Chamraeun Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Ou K. was selected by the other members to be the group leader. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, but all hope to improve their family's living conditions.

Mrs. Ou K. is a farmer who owns a 0.50-hectare (~1.2-acre) plot of land where she grows rice that she sells to support her family. She is also a weaver. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Mrs. Ou K. is asking for a loan to buy more silk to weave silk cloth.   

She was born in 1957. She is a widow with four children, one of whom is a weaver. Another one of her children sells groceries but earns only a small salary. Her other children are studying in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave silk cloth

loans.name: Joseph Chepkaitany

texts.en:
Joseph K. is 60 years old. He is a resident of Kapkiamo in Kabarnet Town. He is married to Talai, a housewife, they have been blessed with 13 children ages between 40 and 20 years. He supports a family 3, since most of his children have their own families.
 
Joseph runs a butcher shop in the Kapkiamo Trading Centre. Most of his customers are residents of the centre and the nearby villages. He started his business four years ago and earns an average profit of Kshs 6,000 a month. Joseph has borrowed Kshs 30,000. This is his fifth loan from KADET LTD. He intends to use all amount to buy animals for slaughter. 
 
He anticipates using the profits from his business to open a retail shop and expand his butcher shop. He hopes to give his second last and last born the best education. He was not able to give his other children such a fine education due to financial constraints.

loans.use: To purchase goats and sheep to slaughter

loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.ru: Юнусов Рахматулло житель города Душанбе. Ему 53 года. Женат. Имеет троих детей. Образование среднее. Жена домохозяйка. Работает мужским парикмахером. Благодаря своему многолетнему опыту в этой области, у него много клиентов. Кредит просит для приобретения инструментов и аксессуаров, чтобы иметь возможность получить больше дохода.
texts.en: Y. Rahmatullo lives in the city of Dushanbe. He's fifty-three years old, married and is a father to three children. His wife is a stay-at-home mom. He graduated from high school, and works as a barber. Because of his many years of experience in the field, he has a lot of clients. He's requesting a loan to acquire a variety of instruments and accessories in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: To acquire a variety of instruments and accessories

loans.name: Ashignov

texts.en: Ashignov N. is 61-year-old single parent with one adult daughter. He and his daughter live together in a ger, a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Hovd Province in Western Mongolia. His only daughter, age 19, attends university. Ashignov operates a coal-selling business in his town.  He purchases coal directly from local mines and uses his large Russian truck to transport it back to his town. Since 1985, he has been driving a big truck and has gained a lot of experience as a driver. He hopes to purchase a larger truck in the future. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to make necessary repairs to his truck to transport more coal.

loans.use: To make necessary repairs to his truck

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. lives in the Kawaala neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.         

Susan sells food. She has been in this business for 6 years. She works 6 days a week. Susan sells her products door-to-door at retail prices. Susan has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more food, such as bananas, beef, sweet and Irish potatoes and yams. In the future, she hopes to own a big hotel and buy a plot of land. 

Susan lives in a home that she rents with electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S., age 36, is a single woman and the mother of four school-aged children. To make a living, Meas S. owns a small store in good location. In her shop, she sells different kinds of goods, such as food, soft drinks, and fish paste. Her children help her with her business. This family normally earns an average of $3.00 per day to help cover their daily living expenses. 

Meas S.'s business is currently doing quite well because she has a skills in public communication. To meet the needs of her family, she is applying for a loan to purchase more fish paste and other goods to sell. Meas S. and her children appear together in the photograph.

loans.use: To purchase more fish paste and other goods to sell.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen N. lives in the Busega neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has one child who is not in school. 

Hellen sells charcoal. She has been in this business for 2 years and she works 7 days a week. Hellen sells her products from home. Hellen has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more charcoal.her main business challenge is transporting the charcoal from Natete to her home in Busega.  She hopes to start going to villages of Luwero for charcoal. Hellen lives in a home that she owns with electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Batnairamdal

texts.en:
Batnairamdal J. is 39 years old. He lives with his wife and three children in Hovd Province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His three children attend the local school where his wife is a teacher. 

Batnairamdal operates a painting and advertisement poster service in his town. He has been engaged this business since 1990 and has gained a lot of experience as a painter. He is a very talented craftsman who produces a variety of fine arts and picture frames. In the future, Batnairamdal plans to operate a picture-frame manufacturing business with help of his sibling in Ulaanbaatar. He is a skillful, communicative and clever artist. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase the materials, tools and supplieshe needs for his picture frame business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials, tools and supplies to manufacture picture frames

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista N. lives in the Kitintale neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school. 

Teopista has a food stall. She has been in this business for over 10 years and she works 7 days a week. Teopista sells her products from home.

Teopista has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bananas, cassava, and sweet potatoes.          Her main business challenges include transportation and ever increasing prices of food. She hopes to start buying food directly from farmers. Teopista lives in a home that she owns. She has electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Bazar

texts.en:
Bazar Y. is 52 years old and lives with his wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd province in Mongolia. Bazar sells firewood with the help of his wife at a local market in his town only during the winter months. In the summer they have a meat trading business to supplement their earnings.

Bazar started his business in 1998 and has since gained much experience in his trade. After many years of successful operation, their business has grown into a stable operation. 

Bazar is a very optimistic and hardworking man. “In the future,” he says, "I would like to expand my business and buy my own car." He is requesting a 2,600,000 MNT loan to purchase more firewood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet B. is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her relatives). Annet lives in the Kawala neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

Annet sells secondhand shoes. She has been in this business for two years, and she works six days out of every week. Annet sells her products door to door at retail prices. She also sells used clothes. The main business challenge for Annet is the rainy season.

Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of shoes. Her goals for her business are to get a permanent business spot and buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand shoes

loans.name: Mrs. Soeng Rem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeng R. is the mother of three children, all of whom are students; they also help their parents in their work. She and her husband, Mr. Pheap Len, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Pheap is also a laborer.

Soeng is the president of the village bank in Cheav Bdei Khang Kaeut village in Takeo province. She was selected by ten loan members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes so as to improve their family's living conditions.

On Soeng’s plantation it is time to grow rice, but she does not have enough rice seed. So to improve production, Mrs. Soeng R. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Enhbat

texts.en:
Enhbat T. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two-year-old son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd province in Mongolia. He is a hardworking and talkative man.

Enhbat operates a taxi service using his own car that was bought by his parents for him in 2008. He began his taxi business that year and has built a stable operation within this short period. In addition, he owns a house with ten rooms, and twenty students rent his house with monthly rent fees of 50,000 MNT for each room.

Enhbat is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to pay half of the cost of his car. In the future, he plans to operate a car repair shop in his yard after remodeling his garage.

loans.use: To pay half of the money for his car

loans.name: Mahmadi

texts.ru: Файзуллоев Махмади проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 61 год. Женат. Имеет семерых детей. Живет вместе с женой и детьми. Жена, домохозяйка. Сыновья предоставляют услугу, такси. Сам Махмади имеет среднетехническое образование. Занимается перевозкой людей по маршруту Душанбе-Рудаки. В этой области более 7 лет. Он хочет продать свою старую машину и купить новую. Кредит берет для приобретения новой автомашины тангем.
texts.en: F. Mahmadi lives in the Rudaki region. He's sixty-one years old, married and is a father to seven children. They live together. His wife is a stay-at-home mom and his sons work as taxi drivers. Mahmadu has a high school level of education and has worked as a cab driver on the Dushanbe-Rudaki route for seven years. He wants to sell his old car and buy a new one. Which is why he's asking for a loan - to buy a new "Tangem".

loans.use: To buy a new Tangem (a car)

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en:
Moeun S. is a 23-year-old married man with no children yet. His wife is a garment worker and earns a fixed salary every month. The couple lives in Kompong Chhnang Province.

Moeun has been employed as a construction worker since 2005, and he earns a profit on average of 1.5 USD per day. In order to earn more money, Moeun wants to buy a secondhand motorcycle to start a new business as a motor taxi driver. This is why he would like to request a loan from Hattha Kaksekar Limited, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle.

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg S. is 41 years old and lives with her husband in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her husband live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her husband is a driver and operates a transportation business using his own truck to supplement his family’s income.

Oyunchimeg manages a clothing business in her town. She started her business in 2004 and has since built a stable operation. After growing her business over the years, her earnings enabled her to buy a car for her family.

Oyunchimeg is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: Rentsenpurev

texts.en: Rentsenpurev H. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and infant son in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife works in the local factory to supplement their family income. Rentsenpurev operates a used consumer goods trading business in his town. He started his business in April, 2010 after moving to his current town. In a short time, he has made much progress in growing his business. He hopes to grow his business further and purchase more products to sell for a profit. For the future, Rentsenpurev says, "My goal is to buy a house and fence for my family." He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes for his second hand products trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 32 years old and married.

Fares is experienced in the car-repair sector. He opened his small business and managed to maintain a good reputation in his area. 

He is requesting a $2,400 loan to cover rental expenses for his work place. His aim is to expand his business, buy new and developed machinery but that can only happen after he pays the rent and secures the place.

loans.use: To cover rental expenses for his work place

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers, labor

loans.name: Hanifa

texts.en:
Hanifa N. lives in the Mengo Kisenyi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children who aren't in school.     Hanifa has a business of selling food and vegetables. She has been in this business for one and a half years, and she works six days out of every week. 

Hanifa sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Hanifa has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions and cabbages. The main business challenges for Hanifa include seasonality and transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only and also to start going to farmers directly.   

Hanifa lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and rent.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Duch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Kampong Luong village in Takeo province, 10 people make up a village bank loan. They have selected Mrs. Srey D. as village bank president and will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in which it can improve their families' living conditions.   

Mrs. Srey D. and her husband, Mr. Saren Sok, are farmers who own a 3-hectare plot of land in which to grow rice to sell to support their family. They also sell mangoes that they grow. She has a problem because her in her field, it is time to grow but she does not have money to support it. So to improve production, Mrs. Srey D. is applying for a loan to do farming this current year.

She is a mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Nyamhuu

texts.en: Nyamhuu D. is 52 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband works as a fireman in the local company while her daughter is a teacher but currently stays at home with her brother. Nyamhuu operates a cafe in a rented space in her town. She started her cafe business in 2009. In addition, she works in the construction decoration field to supplement her earnings. Nyamhuu is a hardworking woman. She is requesting a 700,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to pay rent fees for her cafe and to purchase groceries and meat to make a variety of meals at her cafe.

loans.use: To pay rent fees and purchase groceries and meat

loans.name: Mrs. Reab Chheun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Reab C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the nine people who make up the village bank loan. This loan can improve their family living. They are located in Prey Ba Soeng village in Takeo province. 

She is a knitter who earns some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sitha Bev, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to grow rice to sell to support his family. On this plantation, it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough money to support the crop. So to improve production, Mrs. Reab C. is seeking a loan to do farming this current year. 

She is a mother of two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum M. is a 42-year-old married father. His wife is a tailor, and they have two children who are still living with them.

Sum owns a medium-sized shop next to a local market where he provides a clock repair service, the earnings from which are the family’s main income. He also buys used clocks at reasonable prices from people in the village, repairs them, and then sells them to gain a profit. He started his service in early 2000, and he earns 5 USD per day.

Sum M. will use his loan to buy spare clock parts for his service and used clocks to repair, which he will then resell at a profit.

loans.use: To buy spare clock parts and used clocks to repair

loans.name: Dorgham

texts.en:
The borrower is from Iraq. He is 21 years old.

Dorgham has experience in the grains and seeds’ trade. He works in the field and managed to develop a good reputation in his area.

He is requesting an $1800 loan to buy a new tilling machine for the field. His aim is to enhance his work efficiency and expand to secure a proper income.

loans.use: To buy a new tilling machine for the field

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional related family members. Josephine lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food for her family.

Josephine has a retail shop. She has been in business for ten years, and she works six days out of every week. Her main business challenge is seasonality.

Josephine has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, cartons of salt and boxes of soap. Her goal for her business is to expand it.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Mrs. Samrit An Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samrit A. and her husband, Mr. Sorn Khiev, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land upon which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. They have two children who are employed in garment factories and live in Spueu village in Takeo province. Although they work hard, they earn very little in income.

Samrit was selected by the other fourteen members of their village bank to be the bank loA. president. Each member will use their portion of the loA. for different purposes. Samrit will use her portion of the loA. to buy two piglets and pig feed to start a new pig breeding business. With the rest of the loA. she is going to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy two piglets, pig feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and labor

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 53 years old. He is married and a father of three children.

Muhammad has good experience in the running his business. He opened a minimarket to sell groceries and fulfill the market needs in his area and he maintains a good reputation there.

He is requesting a $2700 loan to install a new door and set up a solid entrance for his store. His aim in the long term is to develop his project and expand later on.

loans.use: To install a new door and set up a solid entrance for his store

loans.name: Joelle M.

texts.fr: Joëlle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Dotée d'une expérience d'au moins 2 ans, Joëlle vend divers articles tels que tomates en boîtes, sardines, mayonnaises, boissons, savons et autres à son domicile sise à Cocotomey, un quartier populeux sis à la banlieue ouest du Bénin. Ses clients sont constitués des ménages de la zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne chez les grossistes à Tokpa, le marché international du Bénin. Elle sollicite et obtient un micro crédit à FINADEV pour achalander son étalage de ces divers articles en quantité suffisante et en qualité appréciable afin de pouvoir combler l'attente de ses clients qui ne cesse de s'agrandir au jour le jour. Puisque la dépense familiale revient au couple; avec le revenu supplémentaire que va générer ce micro crédit elle pourra mieux faire face à ses charges personnelles et aussi contribuer convenablement à l'épanouissement de sa famille. Joëlle souhaiterait ouvrir plupart une autre boutique dans les environs.
texts.en:
Joëlle is married and the mother of three children. Benefiting from at least two years' experience, Joëlle sells various items such as tinned tomatoes, sardines, mayonnaise, drinks, soap, etc. out of her house located in Cocotomey, a working class neighborhood in the western suburbs of Bénin. Her customers come from the households in her neighborhood and surrounding areas. She buys her supplies from wholesalers in Tokpa, the international market of Bénin. 

She has requested and has been granted a small loan from FINADEV to replenish her shelves with these various articles in sufficient quantity and of good enough quality so that she can satisfy the needs of her customers whose numbers are daily growing. 

The couple share in supporting their family, so with the additional income that this small loan should generate, she will be in a better position to cover her personal expenses and also contribute appropriately to improving the living conditions of her family. 

Apart from these goals, Joëlle would like to be able to open up another little shop in her area.

loans.use: stocking up on foodstuffs to sell in her little shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of frozen meat fish, rice, cooking oil, seasonings, etc.

loans.name: Gardashkhan

texts.ru:
Gardashkhan G. 48 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey kotoriye uchatsya v shkole. Gardashkhan yavlyayetsya IDP personom , on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, Seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Gardashkhan uje 8 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji zapchastey, instrumentov  i t.d. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit tovar dlya pereprodaji. Gardashkhan  ochen lubit svoyu rabotu no v dalneyshem on xotel bi otkrit i masterskuyu.
texts.en: Gardashkhan G. is forty-eight years old. He's married and has two children who attend school. Gardashkhan used to live in Fuzuli City, but has moved into the Fuzuli region, where he now lives with his family. For eight years, Gardashkhan has owned a store, specializing in the sale of spare parts, various tools, etc. He's asking for a loan of 2000 AZN in order to acquire some new products for resale. Gardashkhan enjoys his work and plans to add a workshop to his store in the future.

loans.use: To buy goods for resale

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia S. lives in the Makerere Zone C neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school.  She also takes care of her brother.  Sylvia has a retail shop.  She has been in this business for four years, and she works seven days a week. 

Sylvia has requested for a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more merchandise such as bags of sugar, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap.The main business challenges for Sylvia include seasonality and transportation.  Her goals for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to build rentals. 

Sylvia lives in a home, which she owns; she has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding her family.

loans.use: To buy boxes of soap, bags of sugar, and cartons of salt

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 39 years old. He is married and has three children.

In 2009, Samir opened he is own sewing workshop where clothes are produced for all ages and genders. He has become well known in his living area and has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting $2500 to buy a big electric generator so his production will continue in case the electricity is down. He aims to grow bigger and be able to buy more developed machines. This will help him to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a big electric generator

loans.name: Léopoldine J.

texts.fr: Mariée, Léopoldine a à charge 2 enfants, tous scolarisés. Elle est coiffeuse de profession depuis environs 8 ans. Parallèlement à la coiffure, elle commercialise des mèches, des sacs, des chaussures et des produits cosmétiques. Elle compte parmi ses clients les habitants de sa zone et de ses environs. Pour ses activités, Léopoldine s'approvisionne auprès des grossistes à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin et au Togo ou au Nigeria, deux pays frontaliers au Bénin. Elle sollicite et obtient un prêt à FINADEV afin de constituer un stock plus important et plus varié afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients. Son mari prend en charge la majeure partie des dépenses de la famille, mais elle y participe également. Ainsi, avec le revenu supplémentaire généré par ce micro crédit, elle pourra mieux prendre soin de sa famille et d'elle-même. Elle souhaiterait avoir sa propre maison de distribution de gros de ses produits dans les jours à venir.
texts.en:
Léopoldine is married and raising two children, both in school. She has been a professional hairdresser for eight years. Along with hairdressing, she also sells hair extensions, handbags, shoes, and cosmetics. Her clientele is made up of people from her neighborhood and passersby. 

Léopoldine buys her business inventory from wholesalers in Tokpa, the largest market in Bénin, and also in Togo or Nigeria, two countries which border Bénin. She has requested and is being granted a loan from FINADEV so that she can significantly expand and diversify her stock so as to better satisfy her customers. 

Her husband is the major breadwinner for the household, but she also participates in supporting their family.  Thus, with the additional income generated by this small loan, she will be better able to care for her family and herself. She would like in future to have her own wholesale business selling her product line.

loans.use: purchase of boxes of hair extensions and other cosmetic products

loans.name: People Yone Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “People Yone” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Musu T. is the leader of this group. The 22-year-old is married to a businessman and they have three children. Musu has been a businesswoman for five years now. She sells market food – vegetable oil, groundnuts, fish, sugar and other cooking condiments. With her share of this loan, she will be able to expand her business by buying the above mentioned items in larger quantities to add to her current stock. 

(Also included in the right of the photo is loan officer Wallie Mansaray, handing the loan to the clients.)

loans.use: To buy vegetable oil, groundnuts, fish, sugar and cooking condiments in large quantities for resale

loans.name: Kurmanbubu's Group

texts.en:
Kurmanbubu A. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Kochkor, a small town in Isykul region. Kurmanbubu is 56 and married. She has four sons and a daughter. All of them are married and live separately with their families. The sons work in construction and the daughter works at the airport. Twenty years ago, with the initial investment of 3,000 soms, Kurmanbubu started to take orders and sew Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. In this way, she earns 10,000 soms per month. Kurmanbubu applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase wool and paint for sewing. In the future, she wants to expand her business and start building a house for her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase paint and wool

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy gallons of palm oil, dozens of rubber bowls and a wide variety of kitchen utensils to add to her business

loans.name: Madeleine A.

texts.fr: Madeleine est mariée et a 2 enfants. Avec son mari, elle supporte les charges familiales. Elle est coiffeuse de profession depuis 11 ans et a son atelier devant son domicile à Agla, un quartier populeux de la capitale économique du Bénin. Parallèlement à ses prestations de services, elle vend des mèches, des pommades, des shampooing, des démêlants et des cartes de recharge. Elle a aussi un réfrigérateur qui lui permet de vendre de la glace et des boissons de la SOBEBRA, une entreprise qui fabrique des produits de la brasserie. Sa clientèle est composée des habitants de sa zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin pour son salon et les autres articles. En vue de mieux satisfaire ses clients, elle a décidé d'augmenter son fonds de roulement c'est la raison pour laquelle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un micro crédit à FINADEV. Le revenu supplémentaire généré par ce micro crédit pourra l'aider à améliorer la vie quotidienne de sa famille comme par exemple le confort général du foyer. Elle souhaiterait faire la vente en gros et aussi avoir sa propre maison.
texts.en:
Madeleine is married and has two children. Together with her husband, she supports the family. She has been a professional hairdresser for 11 years and  her salon is located in front of her house in Agla, a working-class neighborhood in the economic capital of Bénin. Along with her hairdressing services, she sells hair extensions, pomades, shampoos, conditioners, and rechargeable telephone cards. She also has a refrigerator which means she can sell ice and  drinks from SOBEBRA, a company that brews beer. Her clientele is composed of people from her neighborhood and its surroundings. 

She buys the supplies for her salon as well as the items she sells at Tokpa, the largest market in Bénin. In order to better satisfy her clients, she decided to grow her working capital. This is the reason why she has asked for and been granted a small loan from FINADEV. The supplemental income generated from this small loan will allow her to improve day-to-day living conditions for her family, for example, the general comfort of her home. 

In future, she would like to sell wholesale and also to have her very own home to live in.

loans.use: purchase of beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Habil

texts.ru:
Habil G. 40 let. On jenat i imeyet odnoqo rebonka kotoriy uchitsya v shkole i kotoroqo on ochen lubit. Habil yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione. 

4 qoda tomu nazad Habil nauchilsya bit masnikom u svoyeqo otca i otkril svoy magazin dlya prodaji myasa. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit myaso dlya pereprodaji i uluchsheniya biznessa.
texts.en: Habil G. is forty years old, married and has one dearly loved child that goes to school. Habil used to live in Fuzuli city, but moved out of the city into the region. Four years ago, he learned the trade of a butcher from his father and opened his own store. He's asking for a loan of 2000 AZN to buy meat in order to increase sales.

loans.use: To buy meat for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy large number of rubber bowls to add to her current inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of frozen meat, fish, rice, cooking oil, seasonings, etc

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Elshad

texts.ru:
Elshad X. 50 let on jenat i imeyet 2 detey kotoriye uchatsya v shkole. Elshad yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas porjivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey lubimoy semyoy.

Elshad 8 let tomu nazad reshil zanatsya skotovodstvom , Etomu biznessu yeqo nauchil otec kotoriy ochen klubil svoyu rabotu. Elshad seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit ovec dlya pereprodaji. Tak je Elshad prodayet i sherst ovec delaya iz nix tepliye zimniye veshi.
texts.en:
Elshad X. is 50 years old. He is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. Elshad is an Internally Displaced Person, a refugee form the town of Fuzuli now living in the Fuzuli Region with his beloved family.

Eight years ago Elshad decided to go into the  animal-raising business. He has learned this  trade from his father, who really enjoyed his work. Now Elshad needs 2000 AZN in order to purchase sheep for  resale. Elshad also sells sheep wool and various winter clothing items made of wool.

loans.use: Purchasing sheep

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha, 35 years  old, is a Jordanian micro-entrepreneur. She is married and a mother of four.

Maha’s humble hobby in decorating with flowers and making  straw products turned into a successful business after she attended a specialized course in making basketry  which gave her a belief  in herself and made her realize the great potential of her hobby. Maha started to produce exceptional straw products out of her home to help her husband in generating income for the family and to secure an excellent education for her children.

Maha is requesting a loan of 300 JD to buy raw materials for her enterprise. She is optimistic about the future and planning to open her own shop so her work will be accessed by many customers and she will be known in her field.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her business

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel K. is a 30-year-old married man who has three children. He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by another client who is a registered member. 

Joel is a shoe maker in the Magarini area, where he resides in Malindi town. His business has been in existence for the past six years. This is his second loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings from KADET Ltd. Joel intends to use his loan to buy equipment for his business. He wishes to use the anticipated profit to continue looking after his family and keep on increasing stock. The gentleman hopes that one day, he will get to own a bigger shoe shop in Magarini town.

loans.use: To buy equipment for making and repairing shoes

loans.name: Yusra

texts.en:
With a kind smile in which time has drawn its deep furrows, Yusra welcomes her customers and takes their orders. Yusra, a micor-entrepreneur  from A. Byader – Amman is  57 years old. A hard-working woman and a mother of four, she took advantage of her distinguished abilities in cooking and turned them into a business that brings in a modest income for the family.

Yusra began by making "Maftol" (popular Jordanian food) at home. Afterwards she realized that producing only "Maftol" would not bring in a steady income for the family so she started making homemade pastry and different kinds of sweets. 

Yusra is requesting a loan of 500 JD to buy raw materials for her new business line. She is looking to open a shop for her business instead of working from home and hopes to realize the family dream of having their own home instead of their current rented one.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her new homemade Jordanian foods business

loans.name: Sadraddin

texts.ru:
Sadraddin M. 56 let. On jenat imeyet 3 detey , dva iz kotorix uchatsya v kolledje a odin v shkole. Sadraddin yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy kotoruyu on ochen lubit i delayet vse dlya nix.

On uje 1,5 qoda kak nachal zanimatsya skotovodstvom , Rasnshe on imel magazin no iz za toqo chto maqazin naxodilsya daleko ot yeqo doma i on pravodil tam mnoqo vremeni on reshil zanatsya skotovodstvom chtobi bit blije k svoyey semye. Eto uje vtoraya ssuda Sadraddina on v perviy raz bral 1000 $ i ochen blagodaren lenderam,seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa u uvilicheniya kolichestvo molochnix produktov dlya prodaji sosedam i maqazinam. 

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/52380
texts.en:
Sadraddin M. is 56 years old. He is married and has three children, two of whom are in college and one is in high school. Sadraddin is an Internally Displaced Person, a refugree from the town of Fuzuli now living in the Fuzuli Region together with his family. He loves his family very much does everything for them.

For about 1.5 years he has been raising animals. In the past he used to run a store but, since the store was located far from his home and he spent a lot of time there, he decided to start raising animals in order to be closer to his family. This is Sadraddin’s second loan. The first time he borrowed $1000. He is very grateful to the lenders. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy a cow for growing his business further and increasing the volume of milk products he can sell to his neighbors and to retail stores.

loans.use: Purchasing a cow

loans.name: Emily Jemutai

texts.en:
Emily C. is a 48-year-old widow. She has been blessed with three children, age 22, 16 and 10 years respectively. Emily runs a cereals store at the Emsea trading center in Kabarnet town. Most of her clients are residents of Emsea and nearby villages.

Emily has been in this business for the last eight years. From this business, she gets an average income of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs) a month. She has borrowed a fourth loan of Kshs 60,000 from Kadet Ltd. to expand her business by purchasing maize worth Kshs 30,000, beans worth Kshs 20,000 and 10,000 Kshs for millet and transportation cost.
 
She anticipates to use her profits to repay the loan, pay her workers and pay fees for her children and save the rest. Her dreams and hopes are to be able to save enough to build rental houses on her plot in Eldoret and be able to start another store in Eldoret.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of beans.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.fr: Boniface R. est travailleur de la construction. Il a 53 ans, et il a 2 enfants entre 25 ans et 28 ans. Il va utiliser son pret pour le finissage de une maison d'habitation. Sa strategie pour la croissance de l'affaire est de construire des maisons modernes et chercher des locataires pour les maisons. Il voudrait que son lieu d'habitation sut efficace, et il voudrait aussi augmenter la mode de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Boniface R. is a construction worker. He is 53 years old and has two children aged 25 and 28. 

He intends to use his loan to finish building a dwelling house. His business growth strategy is to build modern homes and seek tenants to occupy them. 

He wants his own home to be functional, and also wishes to improve his family’s living conditions.



.

loans.use: To finish a dwelling house

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
Amer is 39 years old and a father of three. Despite issues of  limited working capital,  Amer was able to open a small grocery store which brings in a meager income for the family.

He  is requesting a loan of 800 JD to buy goods for his shop and increase his working capital. He is looking  to expand his small grocery shop into a supermarket and buy his own house.

loans.use: to buy goods for his shop and increase his working capital

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica B. lives in Nakulabye, the neighborhood of Kampala City.  She is married and has 8 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (two in-laws).  Monica has a business selling local gin.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Monica sells her products in a wholesale shop.  

Monica has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more jerycans of local gin.  The main business challenges for Monica include thieves and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to Kabarole for local gin.  

Monica lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more jerycans of local gin

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, rice and beans

loans.name: Mylene

texts.fr:
Vendeuse des fruits et légumes, célibataire, mère de 2enfants, elle exerce cet activité depuis 15ans et son lieu  est  un carrefour.
Le premier prêt à été très bénéfique pour elle, son chiffre d’affaire à augmenter car de 50000f par jour, elle vendait à 70000f a l'octroi du premier prêt.

Le prêt suivant sera le bien venu pour cette période des grandes pluies car les fruits sont nombreux sur le marché et ils se vendent bien.
Pour cela, elle va renforcer en achetant une  caisse de tomates,  une caisse de choux,    une caisse des aubergines violettes, cinq filets d’oignons,   une caisse des mangues greffées, 1 tas des ciboulettes, un tas des persils et céleris  et autres fruits et légumes de saisons. 
Ses enfants sont en bas âges et elle investie plus dans leurs éducations en les nourrissant convenablement.

Ses ambitions sont elles que elle veut construire  une maison pour sa stabilité.
texts.en:
A seller of fruit and vegetables, this woman is unmarried and the mother of two children.  She has been in this business for fifteen years and is located at the crossroad.  Her first loan was very beneficial for her.  Her sales figures increased by 50,000 francs a day.  She used to have sales of 70,000 francs at the time the first loan was granted.
